repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Program of Essential Social
            Services (PROSSE) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall performance of the operation
            is rated satisfactory. Regardless of the Borrower's
            implementing agencies in fulfilling all requirements for
            information, and reporting on those components supported by
            the Loan, it is less clear however, whether the Program of
            Essential Services (PROSSE) protected the very poor, as
            intended in the original design project. Nevertheless, the
            project prevented the deterioration of human capital gains,
            and built the foundation for measuring efficiency gains in
            social service programs. The key lessons learned show that:
            a) rapid disbursement objectives during a relatively short
            period of time, should be amenable to procurement acceptable
            by both the Bank and the Government; b) the type of
            instrument lending should be considered given the nature of
            the budget support operation, since an investment operation
            leads to confusion on financing and disbursement methods,
            whereas under economic emergencies, a more efficient
            instrument could have been a sector loan; and, c) it is
            essential to base the initial design on solid ground, tying
            strategic objectives with operational procedures rather than
            providing flexibility, which may affect, among others,
            procurement and disbursements.

18225769.theme: Nutrition and food security,Health system performance,Education for all,Other communicable diseases,Improving labor markets
18225769.majtheme: Human development,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Program of Essential Social
            Services (PROSSE) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Program of Essential Social Services
            (PROSSE) Project has three objectives, to: 1) protect
            essential social services for the poor, through the
            provision of textbooks to all students, and on a targeted
            basis, teaching materials, maintaining access to pre-school,
            primary and lower secondary education in isolated rural
            areas, provision of a basic health care package, vaccines,
            pharmaceuticals and medical supplies, and community health
            outreach campaigns to the uninsured population; b)
            strengthen existing social safety net measures, to cushion
            the poor from the effects of the economic crisis through
            retraining, the creation of short term employment
            opportunities for the unemployed and underemployed, and a
            nutrition program targeted to vulnerable groups in the
            poorest areas; and c) lay the foundation for measuring and
            implementing efficiency gains in the social sectors over the
            medium term through technical assistance and program
            monitoring. The PROSSE consists of five componenets: 1)
            basic education services; 2) basic health services; 3)
            retraining and employment generation; 4) an integrated
            nutrition program for vulnerable groups; and 5) monitoring
            and evaluation of social sector programs.

Mexico - Program of Essential Social
